title: Chapter 9 - File and File System Management

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of file and file system management in Linux?

options.text: To compile C programs into binary executables.
To organize, store, access, and protect data on storage devices efficiently.
To manage the graphical user interface themes.
To control the network packet routing protocols.

questions.explanation: The main purpose of file system management is to organize, store, access, and protect data in a structured and efficient way.

questions.question: What is the Linux Filesystem Hierarchy Standard (FHS)?

options.text: A standard that defines the directory structure and contents in Linux systems.
A protocol for transferring files over the network.
A hardware specification for hard drive manufacturing.
A coding standard for the Linux Kernel.

questions.explanation: The FHS defines the directory structure and directory contents in Linux systems .

questions.question: What is the function of the root directory (/) in Linux?

options.text: It stores only the boot loader files.
It acts as a temporary folder for user downloads.
It contains only the administrator's personal files.
It is the top-level directory containing all other directories and files.

questions.explanation: The root directory (/) is the top-level directory containing all other directories. Everything in Linux exists under this single tree structure.

questions.question: What type of data is typically stored in the /etc directory?

options.text: System-wide configuration files (e.g., network settings, user accounts).
Temporary files that are cleared on reboot.
Binary executable files for user commands.

questions.explanation: /etc stores system-wide configuration files like network settings and user accounts, usually as editable text files.

questions.question: What is the role of the /var directory?

options.text: To hold variable data like logs, mail spools, and temporary files persisting across reboots.
To store the Linux kernel image.

questions.explanation: /var contains variable data including logs (/var/log), mail spools, and temporary files that persist across reboots.

questions.question: What characterizes the /tmp directory?

options.text: It stores permanent backups of the system.
It stores user password files securely.
It stores temporary files that are usually cleared on reboot.

questions.explanation: /tmp is used for temporary files which are typically cleared upon system reboot.

questions.question: What are /mnt and /media typically used for?

options.text: Mount points for additional filesystems and removable media (e.g., USB drives).

questions.explanation: /mnt and /media serve as mount points for additional filesystems, with /media often used for removable media like USB drives.

questions.question: What distinguishes an Absolute Path from a Relative Path?

options.text: An absolute path starts from the root (/), while a relative path starts from the current directory.
An absolute path is shorter than a relative path.
An absolute path uses backslashes, while a relative path uses forward slashes.
An absolute path is only for files, while a relative path is only for directories.

questions.explanation: An absolute path specifies the complete location starting from the root (/), whereas a relative path is defined relative to the current working directory .

questions.question: Which path type works regardless of the current working directory?
questions.explanation: Absolute paths work regardless of your current directory because they specify the full path from the root.

questions.question: In Linux paths, what do the symbols '.' and '..' represent?

options.text: '.' is the home directory, '..' is the root directory.
'.' is the parent directory, '..' is the current directory.
'.' is the current directory, '..' is the parent directory.
'.' is a hidden file, '..' is a system file.

questions.explanation: The single dot (.) represents the current directory, and the double dot (..) represents the parent directory.

questions.question: What does the tilde symbol (~) represent in Linux?
questions.explanation: The tilde (~) is a shortcut that references the current user's home directory.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the correct structure of a Linux command?
questions.explanation: The standard command-line syntax is: Command Name, followed by Options/Flags (modifying behavior), followed by Arguments (targets) .

questions.question: How can you access the full manual page for a command like 'ls'?
questions.explanation: The 'man' command (manual) is used to access the full documentation for a command.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'pwd' command?

options.text: To print the working directory (current location).

questions.explanation: pwd stands for Print Working Directory and it displays the current directory you are in.

questions.question: Which command lists directory contents?
questions.explanation: The 'ls' command is used to list the contents of a directory.

questions.question: What is the function of the 'cd' command?
questions.explanation: cd stands for Change Directory and is used to navigate between directories.

questions.question: Which command is used to create an empty file or update its timestamp?
questions.explanation: The 'touch' command creates an empty file if it doesn't exist, or updates the timestamp if it does.

questions.question: Which command is used to create a new directory?
questions.explanation: mkdir stands for Make Directory and is used to create new directories.

questions.question: What does the 'cp' command do?
questions.explanation: cp is the command used to Copy files or directories (with the -r flag).

questions.question: What is the function of the 'mv' command?

options.text: Moves or renames files and directories.

questions.explanation: mv is used to Move files or Rename them if the destination is in the same directory.

questions.question: Which command is used to delete files or directories?
questions.explanation: rm (remove) is the command used to delete files. Adding -r allows deleting directories.

questions.question: Why should the command 'rm -rf /' be avoided?

options.text: It deletes files permanently from the root without confirmation, causing system destruction.
It only deletes the trash folder.
It takes too long to execute.
It creates too many backup files.

questions.explanation: rm -rf / recursively forces deletion starting from the root directory, which can destroy the entire system.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'cat' command?

options.text: To catch errors in a log.
To create a catalog of files.
To display (concatenate) the full contents of a file.

questions.explanation: cat (concatenate) displays the entire contents of a file to the standard output.

questions.question: Which command allows paginated viewing of large files, letting you scroll?
questions.explanation: The 'less' command allows navigating large files without loading the entire file into memory.

questions.question: What do the 'head' and 'tail' commands do respectively?

options.text: Show the beginning and end lines of a file.
Show the largest and smallest files.
Show the header and footer metadata.
Show the most and least accessed files.

questions.explanation: head shows the first lines (default 10) and tail shows the last lines (default 10) of a file.

questions.question: What is the 'find' command used for?

options.text: Searching files in real-time based on criteria like name, size, or type.
Searching for text patterns inside files.
Finding the IP address of a server.

questions.explanation: find searches the filesystem in real-time based on criteria like name, size, type, or modification time.

questions.question: Why might the 'locate' command return stale or missing results compared to 'find'?

options.text: It queries a pre-built database that may not be up to date.
It cannot search outside the home directory.
It only works on text files.

questions.explanation: locate queries a pre-built database (mlocate.db) which is faster but may be outdated if new files were created recently.

questions.question: Which command is used to refresh the database used by 'locate'?
questions.explanation: The 'sudo updatedb' command updates the database used by locate.

questions.question: What is the 'grep' command used for?

options.text: Searching for specific text patterns inside files.

questions.explanation: grep matches text patterns (including regular expressions) within files.

questions.question: What does the 'wc' command count?

options.text: Lines, words, and characters (bytes) in a file.

questions.explanation: wc stands for Word Count, counting lines (-l), words (-w), and characters (-c).

questions.question: What symbol is used for Output Redirection (overwriting)?
questions.explanation: The > symbol redirects output to a file, overwriting it. >> appends to it.

questions.question: What is a 'Pipeline' in Linux command line?

options.text: A way to run commands in the background.
A physical cable connecting the CPU to RAM.
Connecting commands so the output of one becomes the input of another (|).

questions.explanation: Pipelines (using |) connect commands, sending the output (stdout) of the first command as input (stdin) to the next .

questions.question: What are the three permission classes in the Unix permissions model?
questions.explanation: Permissions are defined for the User (owner), the Group, and Others (everyone else).

questions.question: Which command is used to change file permissions?
questions.explanation: chmod (Change Mode) is used to modify the read, write, and execute permissions.

questions.question: What command changes the ownership of a file?
questions.explanation: chown (Change Owner) changes the user and/or group ownership of a file.

questions.question: What is the difference between a Hard Link and a Symbolic Link?

options.text: Hard links point to the file path; Symbolic links share the inode.
Hard links share the same inode; Symbolic links point to the file path.
Hard links work across filesystems; Symbolic links do not.

questions.explanation: Hard links point to the same physical data (inode). Symbolic links are special files that contain a path to the target.

questions.question: What does the 'PATH' environment variable define?

options.text: The location of the user's home directory.
The path to the current script file.
The directories where the shell searches for executable commands.
The network route to the internet.

questions.explanation: PATH defines the list of directories the shell searches when you type a command name.

questions.question: Which command is used to display currently running processes?
questions.explanation: ps (process status) displays information about active processes. 'top' is also used for real-time viewing.

questions.question: What command sends a signal to terminate a process?
questions.explanation: The 'kill' command sends a signal (typically TERM or KILL) to a process to terminate it.

questions.question: What indicates the start of a shell script (Shebang)?
questions.explanation: The shebang (#! /bin/bash) on the first line tells the system which interpreter to use to execute the script.
